Research Focus

Computational cognitive neuroscience researcher specializing in artificial intelligence, human memory modeling, and machine learning. I focus on high-dimensional vector spaces and computational models that simulate memory encoding, retrieval, and inference, offering insights into both biological and artificial systems. Drawing from deep learning architectures, associative learning, and graph-based memory representations, I explore how different methodologies and theoretical frameworks can inform the dynamical structures of memory and cognition in both humans and artificial systems, contributing to the development of interpretable AI models and understanding of human memory.

Currently

I’m building EXD-Net: a computational memory framework that simulates emotional destabilization as the catalyst for identity restructuring. To me, memory isn't static. It learns, drifts, and transforms, and EXD-Net embodies that by integrating dynamical systems theory, attractor state dynamics, and high-dimensional vector space drift. EXD-Net models how memory reconsolidation unfolds in the aftermath of destabilization. Rather than treating instability as noise, EXD-Net frames emotional perturbation as a signal for adaptive learning across both artificial and biological systems.

Research Experience

  • Computational Cognitive Science Researcher Jan 2023 – Present
    UCI Computational Cognitive Neuroscience Lab, Aaron Bornstein, Ph.D.
    • Trained autoencoder models on associative learning tasks to simulate human memory, revealing how latent space capacity shapes learning, planning, and recall.
    • Investigated latent geometries to identify how distributed and sparse bottleneck encodings support individual differences in memory retrieval.
    • Explored graph-based memory representations and entropy-driven structures to bridge biological and artificial memory systems, contributing to interpretable AI.
    • Co-authored publications on representational change, temporal learning sequence effects, and memory constraints in high-dimensional systems.
  • Clinical Data Scientist (Medical Affairs) Jun 2022 – Jun 2025
    Johnson & Johnson MedTech – Biosense Webster Inc.
    • Developed ML models across 500K+ clinical datapoints to identify predictive markers for atrial fibrillation recurrence and stratify patient risk.
    • Implemented statistical inference to investigate hidden correlations between patient characteristics, procedural outcomes, and long-term recurrence risks.
    • Supported multiple global clinical studies with 200+ patients, providing analytics for efficacy tracking and regulatory submissions.
    • Authored clinical protocols, technical reports, and regulatory documentation for internal and external review.
  • AI & Language Model Consultant
    Oct 2024 – April 2025
    (Concurrent with JNJ)
    University of San Diego, Darby Vickers, Ph.D.
    • Developed theoretical frameworks for emergent behavior in LLMs through cross-disciplinary synthesis and collaboration.
    • Analyzed how model complexity relates to emergent human-like behaviors, translating abstract ML principles into intuitive insights.
    • Integrated ML, philosophy, complex systems theory, and cognitive science to guide research direction and support non-technical understanding.
  • Medical Laboratory Researcher Jul 2021 – Apr 2022
    IQVIA – Q2 Solutions
    • Analyzed and validated patient samples and immunological assays for vaccine research on SARS, Ebola, and Dengue viruses.
    • Cultivated and maintained Vero cell lines for infectious disease assays, achieving 100% confluency and high assay reproducibility.
    • Prepared sterile media, reagents, and cell cultures in BSL-2/aseptic laboratory environments, demonstrating expertise in wet lab techniques.
    • Gained foundational exposure to biological data preprocessing and medical lab informatics.

Publications & Presentations

  • Dinh, E. (in development). EXD-Net: Modeling Emotional Memory Destabilization as a Catalyst of Cognitive Reorganization. Framework and initial simulations under development.
  • Zhou, D., Noh, S., Dinh, E., Guo, J., Cooper, K., & Bornstein, A. (in press). Sparse distributed memory constraints drive representational change as a function of temporal learning sequence. In A. Ruggeri, D. Barner, C. Walker, & N. Bramley (Eds.), Proceedings of the 47th Annual Meeting of the Cognitive Science Society. Cognitive Science Society, San Francisco, CA.

Autoencoder models of human graph learning reveal that sparse and dense representations differentially support planning and recall. [Poster presentation]. Society of Neuroscience Annual Conference, Chicago, IL.
